results.title: Nintendo Bad Street Brawler videogame
results.brief_description: (mya2Zstore) NES Bad Street Brawler video game (Power glove)
results.description:
Bad Street Brawler (released as Bop-n Rumble in North America and Street Hassle in Europe) was a classic street fighting game made by Melbourne studio Beam Software in 1987. Beam was the first Australian studios to produce games for NES, and Bad Street Brawler has an infamous place in NES history: it was one of just two games ever designed to be used with the Power Glove, a wearable controller with NES buttons along the forearm that could also detect finger movement. Using the Power Glove with the game unlocked extra fighting moves that could be used in the game.

The Power Glove could have been a perfect match for a street fighting game about punching and kicking your way through waves of enemies, but the controller’s slow reaction times, and sensitive calibration, made it unwieldy to use. Ultimately both the game and Glove were poorly received.
description_for_label:
Bad Street Brawler (released as Bop-n Rumble in North America and Street Hassle in Europe) was a classic street fighting game made by Melbourne studio Beam Software in 1987. Beam was the first Australian studios to produce games for NES, and Bad Street Brawler has an infamous place in NES history: it was one of just two games ever designed to be used with the Power Glove, a wearable controller with NES buttons along the forearm that could also detect finger movement. Using the Power Glove with the game unlocked extra fighting moves that could be used in the game.

The Power Glove could have been a perfect match for a street fighting game about punching and kicking your way through waves of enemies, but the controller’s slow reaction times, and sensitive calibration, made it unwieldy to use. Ultimately both the game and Glove were poorly received.

results.title: Clamshell Apple Laptop
results.brief_description: You probably know what this is, but not what it’s called. Technically it’s the Apple iBook G3 but they’re better known as ‘Clamshells’ because of their curved, colourful design. Introduced in the late 1990s, these fashionable laptops reflected early attempts to offer personalisation through its range of vibrant colours, which also made them stand out in film and TV. In Legally Blonde (2001), Reece Witherspoon’s character is seen lining up to buy one and using it later in class. Sure, this is likely product placement, but it reflects how the entry level computer was targeted at the education market. It was also the first mass consumer product to have WiFi built in. We maintain a large collection of this kind of legacy equipment for use in digital archaeology and preservation of early interactive educational products and artworks.

results.title: Kodak Movie Light and two bulbs
results.brief_description: “Kodak Movie light 220 x 140V 1000W V/XS/200 label on reverse says: do not earth. double insulation. On and Off switch: 250V A.C. only. ELMACO Australian plug: Peaston, 250V 7.5A V/A50/1 Two - Philips Photolita bulbs in their original boxes. Photolita* trademark PF218E 43 Photolita - NM 250V 500W C8 Made in Holland With one instruction pamphlet which has guide numbers of the exposure times.”

details.label: Measurements
display_values: Arms are adjustable. When at right angles to each side: 265 x 565 x 123 mm. When arms are brought in to minimum: 265 x 125 x 123 mm. cord length from base of light to tip of plug: 2600 mm Bulb: 150mm x 110 x 110 mm (each) original box: 163 x 118 x 120 mm Instruction booklet: 147 x 137 mm

results.title: Assorted Film Making Accessories
results.brief_description: “Coated Walz Filter for Color Film housed in original cardboard box. Walz brand clear plastic case with lid and base. Metal rimmed light brown/orange glass lens. Instructions included Kodak Kodachrome 25 colour movie film daylight for 8mm roll (7.5m KM459P) Tin can embossed with Kodak logo on the top. Unused reel of film. Tin sealed together with black duct tape. Original box Envelope Instructions Film price includes processing by Kodak. Mailing envelope enclosed (this has never been used and is folded in a small square) 7.5 metres in length of douible 8mm film on this roll which is intended to yield 15 metres in length of 8mm movies. The additional film at each end serves as leader and trailer for light protection and camera loading. Process before Oct 1979. KM459P CAT 416 9918 Daylight, ASA 25, 15 DIN 2 pairs of mono ear buds to be plugged in to a crystal radio. 1. Brown leather pouch with pink ear bud. 2. Black vinyl puch with cream ear bud. Sunbeam lens brush. Sundry cord in ziplock bag. National brand. Could possibly have been a cord to connect flash. However there doesn’t see to be a donated item which this pairs with. Cyldon brand film reel. (for 8mm) Light metal (tin?). Made in England Markers for 50, 100, 150 and 200 feet.”

results.title: Title Your Films in Colour Austral Plastic Colour Titling Set
results.brief_description: “Title Your Films in Colour, Austral Plastic Colour Titling Set. Present your films in a professional manner by the use of these attractive letters and numbers in full colours. Distributed by Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd. 28 envelopes: 1. Mixture of numbers (21 digits) 2. Zz: 10 letters 3. Yy: 10 letters 4. Xx: 10 letters 5. Ww: 10 letters 6. Vv: 10 letters 7. Uu: 10 letters 8. Tt: 10 letters 9. Ss: 10 letters 10. Rr: 10 letters 11. Qq: 10 letters 12. Pp: 10 letters 13. Oo: 10 letters 14. Nn: 10 letters 15. Mm: 10 letters 16. Ll: 10 letters 17. Kk: 10 letters 18. Jj: 9 letters 19. Ii: 9 letters 20. Hh: 10 letters 21. Gg: 10 letters 22. Ff: 10 letters 23. Ee: 8 letters 24. Dd: 10 letters 25. Cc: 10 letters 26. Bb: 10 letters 27. Symbols/punctuation: 34 symbols.”
